column3: The first letter of the English and of many other alphabets. The capital A of the alphabets of Middle and Western Europe, as also the small letter (a), besides the forms in Italic, black letter, etc., are all descended from the old Latin A, which was borrowed from the Greek Alpha, of the same form; and this was made from the first letter (/) of the Phoenician alphabet, the equivalent of the Hebrew Aleph, and itself from the Egyptian origin. The Aleph was a consonant letter, with a guttural breath sound that was not an element of Greek articulation; and the Greeks took it to represent their vowel Alpha with the a sound, the Phoenician alphabet having no vowel symbols.

Primarily, this word expresses the relations of presence, nearness in place or time, or direction toward; as, at the ninth hour; at the house; to aim at a mark. It is less definite than in or on; at the house may be in or near the house. From this original import are derived all the various uses of at.

is the second letter of the English alphabet. (See Guide to Pronunciation, // 196, 220.) It is etymologically related to p, v, f, w and m , letters representing sounds having a close organic affinity to its own sound; as in Eng. bursar and purser; Eng.  bear and Lat. ferre; Eng. silver and Ger.  silber; Lat. cubitum and It. gomito; Eng. seven, Anglo-Saxon seofon, Ger. sieben, Lat. septem, Gr."epta`, Sanskrit saptan. The form of letter B is Roman, from Greek B (Beta), of Semitic origin. The small b was formed by gradual change from the capital B.

The art or practice of casting horoscopes, or observing the disposition of the stars, with a view to prediction events.

A mass of earthy matter, or rock of the same character as the wall rock, occurring in the course of a vein, as of coal or ore; hence, to take horse -- said of a vein -- is to divide into branches for a distance.

Very large; enormous; immense; excessive; -- used esp. of material bulk, but often of qualities, extent, etc.; as, a huge ox; a huge space; a huge difference.

Not martial; unwarlike.
In an immediate manner; without intervention of any other person or thing; proximately; directly; -- opposed to mediately; as, immediately contiguous.

In like degree; in like manner; seeing that; considering that; since; -- followed by as. See In as much as, under In, prep.

A measure of length, the twelfth part of a foot, commonly subdivided into halves, quarters, eights, sixteenths, etc., as among mechanics. It was also formerly divided into twelve parts, called lines, and originally into three parts, called barleycorns, its length supposed to have been determined from three grains of barley placed end to end lengthwise. It is also sometimes called a prime ('), composed of twelve seconds (''), as in the duodecimal system of arithmetic.
The direction in which a body, or a ray of light or heat, falls on any surface.
Having deep and sharp notches, as a leaf or a petal.
Want of civism; want of patriotism or love to one's country; unfriendliness to one's state or government.
An inclined plane; an ascent o/ descent; a grade or gradient; a slope.
Inclosing; encircling; surrounding.

Not of equal of sufficient measure or extent; not adequate; as, our means are incommensurate to our wants.
Incapable of being together without mutual reaction or decomposition, as certain medicines.
The quality of being incompressible, or incapable of reduction in volume by pressure; -- formerly supposed to be a property of liquids.
Not confutable.

Within the house; -- usually separated, in doors.

On the side of a flower which is next the bract; anterior.

Turned; bent.
Flowing in.
One who, or that which, informs, animates, or vivifies.

To invent; to contrive.
In the form of a globe or sphere; -- applied to nebulous matter collected into a sphere by the force of gravitation.
To work into the natural texture or into the mental or moral constitution of; to stain; to saturate; to imbue; to infix deeply.
A growth or development inward.
Uninhabited.

Permanently existing in something; inseparably attached or connected; naturally pertaining to; innate; inalienable; as, polarity is an inherent quality of the magnet; the inherent right of men to life, liberty, and protection.
A writ from a higher court forbidding an inferior judge from further proceedings in a cause before; esp., a writ issuing from a higher ecclesiastical court to an inferior one, on appeal.
In an inimical manner.
The act of initiating, or the process of being initiated or introduced; as, initiation into a society, into business, literature, etc.
Not according to sound judgment or discretion; unwise; as, an injudicious measure.
Supplying or covering with ink.
To ally, or form an alliance witgh; to unite; to combine.
Originating in, or derived from, the constitution of the intellect, as opposed to acquired from experience; as, innate ideas. See A priori, Intuitive.
Not harmful; free from that which can injure; innoxious; innocuous; harmless; as, an innocent medicine or remedy.

A natural susceptibility, characteristic of all living organisms, tissues, and cells, to the influence of certain stimuli, response being manifested in a variety of ways, -- as that quality in plants by which they exhibit motion under suitable stimulation; esp., the property which living muscle processes, of responding either to a direct stimulus of its substance, or to the stimulating influence of its nerve fibers, the response being indicated by a change of form, or contraction; contractility.

A complex nitrogenous radical, C8H4NO2, regarded as the essential residue of a series of compounds, related to isatin, which easily pass by reduction to indigo blue.
One of the asteroids.
Indicating equal barometric pressure.
Having the quality of isodimorphism.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, equality of measure.
Of equal value.
The act of issuing, or giving out; as, the issuance of an order; the issuance of rations, and the like.
Same as Ixtle.
To print in Italic characters; to underline written letters or words with a single line; as, to Italicize a word; Italicizes too much.
By way of iteration.
Any carving executed in ivory.
One of several large wading birds of the genera Mycteria and Xenorhynchus, allied to the storks in form and habits.

A portable machine variously constructed, for exerting great pressure, or lifting or moving a heavy body through a small distance. It consists of a lever, screw, rack and pinion, hydraulic press, or any simple combination of mechanical powers, working in a compact pedestal or support and operated by a lever, crank, capstan bar, etc. The name is often given to a jackscrew, which is a kind of jack.

A large and powerful feline animal (Felis onca), ranging from Texas and Mexico to Patagonia. It is usually brownish yellow, with large, dark, somewhat angular rings, each generally inclosing one or two dark spots. It is chiefly arboreal in its habits. Called also the American tiger.
Same as Jemidar.
Producing discordant sounds.

A church solemnity or ceremony celebrated at Rome, at stated intervals, originally of one hundred years, but latterly of twenty-five; a plenary and extraordinary indulgence grated by the sovereign pontiff to the universal church. One invariable condition of granting this indulgence is the confession of sins and receiving of the eucharist.
To assume the right to pass judgment on another; to sit in judgment or commendation; to criticise or pass adverse judgment upon others. See Judge, v. t., 3.
Of or relating to a court; judicial.

To pass by a spring or leap; to overleap; as, to jump a stream.
The line or point at which two bodies are joined; a joint; an articulation; a seam; as, the junctures of a vessel or of the bones.

A yellow carangoid fish of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts (Caranx chrysos), most abundant southward, where it is valued as a food fish; -- called also hardtail, horse crevalle, jack, buffalo jack, skipjack, yellow mackerel, and sometimes, improperly, horse mackerel. Other species of Caranx (as C. fallax) are also sometimes called jurel.
Barely; merely; scarcely; only; by a very small space or time; as, he just missed the train; just too late.
To treat as if righteous and just; to pardon; to exculpate; to absolve.
The state or quality of being juvenile; juvenility.
The colugo.
See 3d Calender.
A native of the Sandwich Islands.

The indirect division of cells in which, prior to division of the cell protoplasm, complicated changes take place in the nucleus, attended with movement of the nuclear fibrils; -- opposed to karyostenosis. The nucleus becomes enlarged and convoluted, and finally the threads are separated into two groups which ultimately become disconnected and constitute the daughter nuclei. Called also mitosis. See Cell development, under Cell.
of Keckle
A cooler; a vat for cooling wort, etc.
To record transactions, accounts, or events in; as, to keep books, a journal, etc.  ; also, to enter (as accounts, records, etc. ) in a book.

Cloth with the nap, generally of native black wool.
To put or keep in a kennel.

One of a large class of organic substances resembling the aldehydes, obtained by the distillation of certain salts of organic acids and consisting of carbonyl (CO) united with two hydrocarbon radicals. In general the ketones are colorless volatile liquids having a pungent ethereal odor.
To fasten or secure firmly; to fasten or tighten with keys or wedges.

Jagged, or slashed irregularly, at the end, or along the edge.
Having the form of a tear; tear-shaped.

A game of ball, originating among the North American Indians, now the popular field sport of Canada, and played also in England and the United States. Each player carries a long-handled racket, called a "crosse". The ball is not handled but caught with the crosse and carried on it, or tossed from it, the object being to carry it or throw it through one of the goals placed at opposite ends of the field.

The ceiling or under surface of any part, especially when it consists of compartments, sunk or hollowed without spaces or bands between the panels.

A group of birds embracing the Anseres and flamingoes, in which the bill is lamellate.
A genus of great seaweeds with long and broad fronds; kelp, or devil's apron. The fronds commonly grow in clusters, and are sometimes from thirty to fifty feet in length. See Illust. of Kelp.

One of the small paper cases filled with combustible composition, which mark the outlines of a figure.
The solid part of the surface of the earth; -- opposed to water as constituting a part of such surface, especially to oceans and seas; as, to sight land after a long voyage.

The expanded upper end of the windpipe or trachea, connected with the hyoid bone or cartilage. It contains the vocal cords, which produce the voice by their vibrations, when they are stretched and a current of air passes between them. The larynx is connected with the pharynx by an opening, the glottis, which, in mammals, is protected by a lidlike epiglottis.

Wanting flesh; destitute of or deficient in fat; not plump; meager; thin; lank; as, a lean body; a lean cattle.
from Leap, to jump.
A thong of leather, or a long cord, by which a falconer holds his hawk, or a courser his dog.
Liberty granted by which restraint or illegality is removed; permission; allowance; license.
Coagulated sour milk diluted with water; -- a common beverage among the Arabs. Also, a fermented liquor made of the same.
To reprove formally and with authority.
Any one of numerous genera and species of annulose worms, belonging to the order Hirudinea, or Bdelloidea, esp. those species  used in medicine, as Hirudo medicinalis of Europe, and allied species.
of Let, to allow.
To use as a leg, with it as object
The place of business or official residence of a diplomatic minister at a foreign court or seat of government.
Having long legs.
The state, or quality, of being legitimate, or in conformity with law; hence, the condition of having been lawfully begotten, or born in wedlock.
Belonging to, or resembling, a very large natural order of plants (Leguminosae), which bear legumes, including peas, beans, clover, locust trees, acacias, and mimosas.
One of two oval bodies hanging from the interior walls of the body in the Acanthocephala.
Longer; longest; -- obsolete compar. and superl. of long.
The state or quality of being lenient; mildness of temper or disposition; gentleness of treatment; softness; tenderness; clemency; -- opposed to severity and rigor.
Alt. of Lentisk
Leprous; infectious; corrupting; poisonous.
Of or pertaining to the Leptocardia.
A smaller portion or quantity.
of Let
Sulphuric ether used as an anaesthetic agent.
Of or pertaining to a branch of the Slavic family, subdivided into Lettish, Lithuanian, and Old Prussian.
Pertaining to, or designating, a complex organic acid, obtained as a yellowish white gum by the oxidation of croconic acid.
A stout twilled silk fabric, formerly made in the Levant.
of Level
One who levies.
Lack of gravity and earnestness in deportment or character; trifling gayety; frivolity; sportiveness; vanity.
A lewd person.
A Chinese copper coin; a cash. See Cash.
of Libel
One who, or that which, liberalizes.
A curve or arch in a bit to afford room for the tongue of the horse.
Of or pertaining to Libya, the ancient name of that part of Africa between Egypt and the Atlantic Ocean, or of Africa as a whole.
A description of lichens; the science which illustrates the natural history of lichens.

An officer who bore an ax and fasces or rods, as ensigns of his office. His duty was to attend the chief magistrates when they appeared in public, to clear the way, and cause due respect to be paid to them, also to apprehend and punish criminals.
A popular name for any society or club which meets for the practice of male part songs.
An officer who supplies the place of a superior in his absence; a representative of, or substitute for, another in the performance of any duty.
Lasting or continuing through life.
A lift gate. See Lift gate, below.
To lie or recline.
Not encumbered; unembarrassed; clear of impediments; hence, active; nimble; swift.
To grow lighter; to become less dark or lowering; to brighten; to clear, as the sky.
With little weight; with little force; as, to tread lightly; to press lightly.
Yielding or producing wood.
A strap-shaped corolla of flowers of Compositae.
Similar; like; alike.
An Australian myrtaceous tree (Eugenia Smithii), having smooth ovate leaves, and panicles of small white flowers. The wood is hard and fine-grained.
The border or edge of the disk of a heavenly body, especially of the sun and moon.
To treat with lime, or oxide or hydrate of calcium; to manure with lime; as, to lime hides for removing the hair; to lime sails in order to whiten them.
A limiter. See Limiter, 2.
A city of Southern France.

The only existing genus of Merostomata. It includes only a few species from the East Indies, and one (Limulus polyphemus) from the Atlantic coast of North America. Called also Molucca crab, king crab, horseshoe crab, and horsefoot.
A more or less threadlike mark of pen, pencil, or graver; any long mark; as, a chalk line.
A measure of length; one twelfth of an inch.
Marked with little lines.
See Lingel.
A torch made of tow and pitch, or the like.

Any viverrine mammal of the genus Prionodon, inhabiting the East Indies and Southern Asia. The common East Indian linsang (P. gracilis) is white, crossed by broad, black bands. The Guinea linsang (Porana Richardsonii) is brown with black spots.
A name given in Western South America to certain plants with shaggy tomentose leaves, as species of Culcitium, and Espeletia.
A tumor consisting of fat or adipose tissue.
Fluid and transparent; as, the liquid air.
Eagerly desirous. See Lickerish.
A line inclosing or forming the extremity of a piece of ground, or field of combat; hence, in the plural (lists), the ground or field inclosed for a race or combat.
One who listens; a hearkener.
To make literal; to interpret or put in practice according to the strict meaning of the words; -- opposed to spiritualize; as, to literalize Scripture.
Mild; calm; as, lithe weather.
Of or pertaining to the art of cutting and engraving precious stones.
Pertaining to lithophosphor; becoming phosphoric by heat.
A native, or one of the people, of Lithuania; also, the language of the Lithuanian people.
One who occupies himself with literature; a literary man; a literatus.
A curved staff used by the augurs in quartering the heavens.
Briskness; activity; effervescence, as of liquors.
Hence, any characteristic dress or outward appearance.
A French money of account, afterward a silver coin equal to 20 sous. It is not now in use, having been superseded by the franc.
The charge of a firearm; as, a load of powder.
A loanin.
of Lob

A genus of plants, including a great number of species. Lobelia inflata, or Indian tobacco, is an annual plant of North America, whose leaves contain a poisonous white viscid juice, of an acrid taste. It has often been used in medicine as an emetic, expectorant, etc. L. cardinalis is the cardinal flower, remarkable for the deep and vivid red color of its flowers.
To make local; to fix in, or assign to, a definite place.
That part or apparatus of a firearm by which the charge is exploded; as, a matchlock, flintlock, percussion lock, etc.
A place where persons under arrest are temporarily locked up; a watchhouse.
The spikelet or flower cluster of grasses.
To lay down; to prostrate.
A weight or block near the free end of a hoisting rope to prevent it from being drawn through the sheave.
The business of felling trees, cutting them into logs, and transporting the logs to sawmills or to market.
The divine Word; Christ.
To let the tongue hang from the mouth, as an ox, dog, or other animal, when heated by labor; as, the ox stood lolling in the furrow.
A characteristic of Londoners; a mode of speaking peculiar to London.
Through the whole extent or duration.
The art or practice of measuring distances or lengths.
One of a class of laborers employed about the wharves of a seaport, especially in loading and unloading vessels.
An awkward, clumsy fellow; a lubber.
Object or duty of forethought and care; responsibility.
The running together of the matter of an ore into a mass, when the ore is only heated for calcination.
The state, condition, or quality, of being loose; as, the looseness of a cord; looseness of style; looseness of morals or of principles.

A very singular rodent (Lophiomys Imhausi) of Northeastern Africa. It is the only known representative of a special family (Lophiomyidae), remarkable for the structure of the skull. It has handlike feet, and the hair is peculiar in structure and arrangement.

A titled nobleman., whether a peer of the realm or not; a bishop, as a member of the House of Lords; by courtesy; the son of a duke or marquis, or the eldest son of an earl; in a restricted sense, a boron, as opposed to noblemen of higher rank.
That which is taught; hence, instruction; wisdom; advice; counsel.
of Lorry
Failure to use advantageously; as, loss of time.
See Lotto.
of Lounge
A feeling of strong attachment induced by that which delights or commands admiration; preeminent kindness or devotion to another; affection; tenderness; as, the love of brothers and sisters.
One who deals in affairs of love.
Made, as a vowel, with a low position of part of the tongue in relation to the palate; as, / (/m), / (all). See Guide to Pronunciation, // 5, 10, 11.
Compar. of Low, a.
Low condition, especially as to manner of life.
Anything in the form of lozenge.
Shining; bright; resplendent.

That which happens to a person; an event, good or ill, affecting one's interests or happiness, and which is deemed casual; a course or series of such events regarded as occurring by chance; chance; hap; fate; fortune; often, one's habitual or characteristic fortune; as, good, bad, ill, or hard luck. Luck is often used for good luck; as, luck is better than skill.
Sportive; ridiculous; wanton.
An Indian falcon (Falco jugger), similar to the European lanner and the American prairie falcon.
To fill or encumber with lumber; as, to lumber up a room.
of Lump

The period of a synodic revolution of the moon, or the time from one new moon to the next; varying in length, at different times, from about 29/ to 29/ days, the average length being 29 d., 12h., 44m., 2.9s.

Any one of several species of parasitic nematoid worms which infest the lungs and air passages of cattle, sheep, and other animals, often proving fatal. The lungworm of cattle (Strongylus micrurus) and that of sheep (S. filaria) are the best known.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, hops; specifically, designating an acid obtained by the decomposition of lupulin.
of Lurk
A period of five years; a lustrum.
The act of lustrating or purifying.
A combining form signifying orange yellow or brownish yellow.
Exuberant in growth; rank; excessive; very abundant; as, a luxuriant growth of grass; luxuriant foliage.
An association for debate and literary improvement.
A dog held in a leam; a bloodhound; a limehound.
Any one of several species of feline animals of the genus Felis, and subgenus Lynx. They have a short tail, and usually a pencil of hair on the tip of the ears.
The European pollack; -- called also laith, and leet.
To cover, as a road, or street, with small, broken stones, so as to form a smooth, hard, convex surface.
A kind of spice; the aril which partly covers nutmegs. See Nutmeg.
To plan; to contrive; esp., to form a scheme with the purpose of doing harm; to contrive artfully; to plot.
Same Macule.
Long-jawed.
Any marine bivalve shell of the genus Mactra, and allied genera. Many species are known. Some of them are used as food, as Mactra stultorum, of Europe. See Surf clam, under Surf.
See Eggplant.
The magpie.
A composer of madrigals.
A magician.
A precipitate; a fine substance deposited by precipitation; -- applied in old chemistry to certain white precipitates from metallic solutions; as, magistery of bismuth.
One of the nobility, or certain high officers of state belonging to the noble estate in the national representation of Hungary, and formerly of Poland.
To communicate magnetic properties to; as, to magnetize a needle.
To increase the importance of; to augment the esteem or respect in which one is held.
See Maul-stick.
An unmarried woman; usually, a young unmarried woman; esp., a girl; a virgin; a maiden.
Fig. : Aiding, or tending to, the definition and interpretation of thoughts or language.
To mutilate; to cripple; to injure; to disable; to impair.
A writ directed to the sheriff, commanding him to take sureties, called mainpernors, for the prisoner's appearance, and to let him go at large. This writ is now obsolete.
Mastery; superiority; art. See Mastery.
The quality or condition of being major or greater; superiority.
To tend; to contribute; to have effect; -- with for or against; as, it makes for his advantage.
A town and district upon the seacoast of the Malay Peninsula.
An indefinite feeling of uneasiness, or of being sick or ill at ease.
A West African arboreal monkey (Cercopithecus cynosurus).
Evil doing, esp. to others.
Proceeding from hatred or ill will; dictated by malice; as, a malicious report; malicious mischief.

In the army, a soldier who feigns himself sick, or who induces or protracts an illness, in order to avoid doing his duty; hence, in general, one who shirks his duty by pretending illness or inability.
See Mollemoke.
Barley or other grain, steeped in water and dried in a kiln, thus forcing germination until the saccharine principle has been evolved. It is used in brewing and in the distillation of whisky.
Malmsey wine. See Malmsey.
Having small nipples, or small protuberances like nipples or mammae.
One of the piece with which certain games, as chess or draughts, are played.
A contriver; an intriguer.
An official or authoritative command; an order or injunction; a commission; a judicial precept.

A low plant (Mandragora officinarum) of the Nightshade family, having a fleshy root, often forked, and supposed to resemble a man. It was therefore supposed to have animal life, and to cry out when pulled up. All parts of the plant are strongly narcotic. It is found in the Mediterranean region.
To manage with address or art; to scheme.
To mutilate or injure, in making, doing, or pertaining; as, to mangle a piece of music or a recitation.
Alt. of Manichee
A cylindrical pipe fitting, having a number of lateral outlets, for connecting one pipe with several others.

To use the hands in dexterous operations; to do hand work; specifically, to manage the apparatus or instruments used in scientific work, or in artistic or mechanical processes; also, specifically, to use the hand in mesmeric operations.
Characteristic mode of acting, conducting, carrying one's self, or the like; bearing; habitual style.
A tract of land occupied by tenants who pay a free-farm rent to the proprietor, sometimes in kind, and sometimes by performing certain stipulated services.
A woman's cloak or mantle.
See Manteau.
A building or place where anything is manufactured; a factory.
Relating to manures.

A tree of the genus Acer, including about fifty species. A. saccharinum is the rock maple, or sugar maple, from the sap of which sugar is made, in the United States, in great quantities, by evaporation; the red or swamp maple is A. rubrum; the silver maple, A. dasycarpum, having fruit wooly when young; the striped maple, A. Pennsylvanium, called also moosewood. The common maple of Europe is A. campestre, the sycamore maple is A. Pseudo-platanus, and the Norway maple is A. platanoides.
Cold; hard; unfeeling; as, a marble breast or heart.

A territorial border or frontier; a region adjacent to a boundary line; a confine; -- used chiefly in the plural, and in English history applied especially to the border land on the frontiers between England and Scotland, and England and Wales.
A kind of large yellow rose.
Of or pertaining to a margin.
A picture representing some marine subject.
Attention, regard, or respect.
To deal in a market; to buy or sell; to make bargains for provisions or goods.
Consisting or partaking of marl; resembling marl; abounding with marl.
A marquis.
A bone containing marrow; pl. ludicrously, knee bones or knees; as, to get down on one's marrowbones, i. e., to kneel.

A ministerial officer, appointed for each judicial district of the United States, to execute the process of the courts of the United States, and perform various duties, similar to those of a sheriff. The name is also sometimes applied to certain police officers of a city.
The pecten in the eye of birds and reptiles. See Pecten.
The martin.
of Marvel
A mesh.
The dress or disguise of a maske/; masquerade.
To conceal with masks; to disguise.
Forming, or consisting of, a large mass; compacted; weighty; heavy; massy.
Inclined to play the master; domineering; imperious; arbitrary.
A kind of cement composed of burnt clay, litharge, and linseed oil, used for plastering walls, etc.
Resembling the nipple or the breast; -- applied specifically to a process of the temporal bone behind the ear.
An agreement, compact, etc.
To checkmate.
of Materialize
A fat herring with undeveloped roe.
Hence, that which gives form or origin to anything
That which one has to treat, or with which one has to do; concern; affair; business.
The process of bringing, or of coming, to maturity; hence, specifically, the process of suppurating perfectly; the formation of pus or matter.
Alt. of Maudeline

A member of the Congregation of Saint Maur, an offshoot of the Benedictines, originating in France in the early part of the seventeenth century. The Maurists have been distinguished for their interest in literature.
of Maxilla
Possibility; uncertainty.
Confusion of thought; perplexity; uncertainty; state of bewilderment.
Destitute of richness, fertility, strength, or the like; defective in quantity, or poor in quality; poor; barren; scanty in ideas; wanting strength of diction or affluence of imagery.
Of poor quality; as, mean fare.

A number which is contained in a given number a number of times without a remainder; as in the phrases, the common measure, the greatest common measure, etc., of two or more numbers.
An instrument for cutting into the urethra so as to enlarge its orifice.
An ideal machine; a combination of movable bodies constituting a machine, but considered only with regard to relative movements.
A designer of medals.
A median line or point.
Of, pertaining to, or having to do with, the art of healing disease, or the science of medicine; as, the medical profession; medical services; a medical dictionary; medical jurisprudence.
Same as Para.
A trade name for printing and writing paper of certain sizes. See Paper.
Resembling a medusa in shape or structure.
To assemble together; to congregate; as, Congress meets on the first Monday of December.
See Meg-.
One of the larger measures of electro-motive force, amounting to one million volts.
A morbid condition in which the blood contains black pigment either floating freely or imbedded in the white blood corpuscles.
A group of the human race, including the dark whites.
Consisting of or containing matter like honey; -- said of certain encysted tumors.
See Mellitic.
A mill.
A picture produced by a process in which development after exposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportation of exposed plates; also, the process itself.
Relating to a member.
A memorandum; a record.
One who menaces.
Amendment.

One of a small denomination of Christians, so called from Menno Simons of Friesland, their founder. They believe that the New Testament is the only rule of faith, that there is no original sin, that infants should not be baptized, and that Christians ought not to take oath, hold office, or render military service.
Having the monthly flow or discharge; menstruating.
A wise and faithful counselor or monitor.
Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; now restricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens.
Having the form or image of Mercury; -- applied to ancient guideposts.
Compassionate treatment of the unfortunate and helpless; sometimes, favor, beneficence.
A great circle of the sphere passing through the poles of the heavens and the zenith of a given place. It is crossed by the sun at midday.
An old Scotch silver coin; a mark or marc.
Laughingly gay; overflowing with good humor and good spirits; jovial; inclined to laughter or play ; sportive.
It seems to me.
Of, pertaining to, or induced by, mesmerism; as, mesmeric sleep.
The layer of the blastoderm, between the ectoderm and endoderm; mesoblast. See Illust. of Blastoderm and Ectoderm.
Of or pertaining to the mesopodialia or to the parts of the limbs to which they belong.
Contempt; scorn.
An associate in a mess.
To change by a metabolic process. See Metabolism.
The broken stone used in macadamizing roads and ballasting railroads.
of Metallize
Subject to change; changeable; variable.
A verbal translation; a version or translation from one language into another, word for word; -- opposed to paraphrase.
A salt of metastannic acid.
One who cultivates land for a share (usually one half) of its yield, receiving stock, tools, and seed from the landlord.
Influenced by the weather; as, meteoric conditions.
A yard, staff, or rod, used as a measure.
To reduce to method; to dispose in due order; to arrange in a convenient manner; as, to methodize one's work or thoughts.
Alt. of Metoposcopical
The superior or presiding bishop of a country or province.
An alley where there are stables; a narrow passage; a confined place.
A mineral of an iron-black color, and very sectile, consisting principally of sulphur, antimony, and silver.
Having a small brain.
The millionth part of a farad.
The science which treats of the means of increasing the intensity of low or weak sounds, or of the microphone.
The art of using the microtome; investigation carried on with the microtome.
of Middleman
See Diaphragm, n., 2.
To offend slightly.
Same as Mileage.
The same Milliolitic.
One who milks; also, a mechanical apparatus for milking cows.
To make a raised border around the edges of, or to cut fine grooves or indentations across the edges of, as of a coin, or a screw head; also, to stamp in a coining press; to coin.
A sulphide of nickel, commonly occurring in delicate capillary crystals, also in incrustations of a bronze yellow; -- sometimes called hair pyrites.
The quotient of a unit divided by one million; one of a million equal parts.

In a minatory manner; with threats.
Bearing in mind; regardful; attentive; heedful; observant.
To transform into a mineral.
In a mingling manner.
Minute.
A representative of a government, sent to the court, or seat of government, of a foreign nation to transact diplomatic business.
Any of numerous small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus, and related genera. They live both in fresh and in salt water. Called also killifish, minny, and mummichog.
The duty paid to the mint for coining.
of Minuteman
See Nitrobenzene.
To account or reckon wrongly.
To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand.
To suit ill.
Ill luck; ill fortune; mishap.
Discomfort.
To counsel or advise wrongly.
To turn or divert improperly; to misdirect.
Having discomfort or misery; troubled.
Great unhappiness; extreme pain of body or mind; wretchedness; distress; woe.
To frame wrongly.
Unhappy.
To kindle amiss; to inflame to a bad purpose; to excite wrongly.
Raining in very small drops.
Wrong passion or feeling.
To pronounce incorrectly.
To make an incorrect or untrue representation.
To speak evil of; to slander.
A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate.
An affectionate, or contemptuous, form of miss; a young girl; a miss.
of Mistell
A wrong tradition.
To turn amiss; to pervert.
To write incorrectly.
To make mild and accessible; to mollify; -- applied to persons.
To associate; to mingle.
The art of memory; a system of precepts and rules intended to assist the memory; artificial memory.
Easily moved in feeling, purpose, or direction; excitable; changeable; fickle.
Imitation; mimicry.
The scale as affected by the various positions in it of the minor intervals; as, the Dorian mode, the Ionic mode, etc., of ancient Greek music.
Limited as to the degree in which a quality, principle, or faculty appears; as, an infusion of moderate strength; a man of moderate abilities.
of Modernize
of Modius
A thin silk stuff made in Caucasia.
A spot; a defilement.
Same as 2d Molar.
Capable of being molded or formed.
Any insectivore of the family Talpidae. They have minute eyes and ears, soft fur, and very large and strong fore feet.
The doctrines of the Molinists, somewhat resembling the tenets of the Arminians.
A pet or colloquial name for Mary.
Of, pertaining to, or containing, molybdenum; specif., designating those compounds in which molybdenum has a lower valence as contrasted with molybdic compounds.
Having one hydrogen atom replaceable by a negative or acid atom or radical; capable of neutralizing a monobasic acid; -- said of bases, and of certain metals.
One of a sect in the early Christian church which rejected the doctrine of the Trinity; -- called also patripassian.
The moon.
An authorized coiner of money.
One who monishes; an admonisher.

Having but one finger or claw.
Same as Monogamian.
Representation by lines without color; an outline drawing.
One who believes in monometallism as opposed to bimetallism, etc.
A suborder of Dipnoi, including the Ceratodus.
A monospermous plant.
A single unvaried tone or sound.
My lord; -- an ecclesiastical dignity bestowed by the pope, entitling the bearer to social and domestic rank at the papal court. (Abbrev. Mgr.)
An ancient kind of cap worn by horsemen or huntsmen.
of Moo
Of or resembling the moon; symbolized by the moon.
A preparation of eggs for food.
Land consisting of a moor or moors.
of Mop
The doctrine or practice of the duties of life; manner of living as regards right and wrong; conduct; behavior; -- usually in the plural.
A salt of moric acid.
An embellishment resembling a trill.

Pertaining to, in the manner of, or designating, a kind of marriage, called also left-handed marriage, between a man of superior rank and a woman of inferior, in which it is stipulated that neither the latter nor her children shall enjoy the rank or inherit the possessions of her husband.
A genus of sea birds, having a large, thick bill; the puffin.
Morose.
A Moorish pike.
of Mortalize
One who, or that which, mortifies.

The sphere or globular mass of cells (blastomeres), formed by the clevage of the ovum or egg in the first stages of its development; -- called also mulberry mass, segmentation sphere, and blastosphere. See Segmentation.
A bog; a morass; a place containing peat; as, the mosses of the Scottish border.
A word; hence, a motto; a device.
Thick, like mother; viscid.
To make a significant movement or gesture, as with the hand; as, to motion to one to take a seat.
Of or pertaining to motorpathy.

An artificial hill or elevation of earth; a raised bank; an embarkment thrown up for defense; a bulwark; a rampart; also, a natural elevation appearing as if thrown up artificially; a regular and isolated hill, hillock, or knoll.
Inhabiting mountains.
The act of sorrowing or expressing grief; lamentation; sorrow.
To sport with roughly; to rumple.
As much as is usually put into the mouth at one time.
Motion of the mind or feelings; emotion.
A heap or mass of hay or of sheaves of grain stowed in a barn.
A thing uncommon, wonderful, or noticeable; something considerable.
A miser; a niggard.
A brown, amorphous, bitter substance having a strong emetic action, extracted from the root of the mudar.
Same as Moodir.
A cushion for terminating or softening a note made by a stringed instrument with a keyboard.
The offspring of a negress by a white man, or of a white woman by a negro, -- usually of a brownish yellow complexion.
In the manner or condition of a mulier; in wedlock; legitimately.
A cow.
Having many teeth, or toothlike processes.
Same as Multinodate.
To increase in number; to make more numerous; to add quantity to.
Wandering much.
A game of hazard played with cards in silence.
of Mump
Remuneration.
Any one of several species of small Asiatic deer of the genus Cervulus, esp. C. muntjac, which occurs both in India and on the East Indian Islands.
Prepared with chloride of silver through the agency of common salt.
A catarrh.
An old name for mosses in the widest sense, including the true mosses and also hepaticae and sphagna.
Mica; muscovite. See Mica.
A small hole or gap through which a wild animal passes; a muse.
The perfume emitted by musk, or any perfume somewhat similar.
See Musket.
A mustache.
Change; alteration, either in form or qualities.
A mutineer.
The act of borrowing or exchanging.
One who is versed in, or who studies, mycology.
Pertaining to, or in the region of, the lower jaw and the hyoid apparatus; as, the mylohyoid nerve.
Divination by the movements of mice.
A metric weight, consisting of ten thousand grams or ten kilograms. It is equal to 22.046 lbs. avoirdupois.
A ferment, resembling diastase, found in mustard seeds.
of Mystery
A fabulous narrative; a myth.
One who returns to Europe from the East with immense riches: hence, any man of great wealth.
Having a true natural luster without being cut; -- applied by jewelers to a precious stone.
Unprovided with needful or desirable accessories, means of sustenance, etc.; destitute; unaided; bare.
Undistinguished; not noted or famous.
A perfume distilled from orange flowers.
A supporter of the dynasty of the Napoleons.
An Australian name for Marsilea Drummondii, a four-leaved cryptogamous plant, sometimes used for food.
A narrow passage; esp., a contracted part of a stream, lake, or sea; a strait connecting two bodies of water; -- usually in the plural; as, The Narrows of New York harbor.
One of the nasal bones.
The quality or state of being nasty; extreme filthness; dirtiness; also, indecency; obscenity.
The two anterior of the four lobes on the dorsal side of the midbrain of most mammals; the anterior optic lobes.
The quality or state of being national; nationality.
Springing from true sentiment; not artifical or exaggerated; -- said of action, delivery, etc.; as, a natural gesture, tone, etc.
The existing system of things; the world of matter, or of matter and mind; the creation; the universe.
of Nauplius
Of or pertaining to Navarre.
The officers and men attached to the war vessels of a nation; as, he belongs to the navy.
At a little distance, in place, time, manner, or degree; not remote; nigh.
A building for the shelter of neat cattle.
The quality of being necessary.
A reduction in size near the end of an object, formed by a groove around it; as, a neck forming the journal of a shaft.

Secreting nectar; -- said of blossoms or their parts.
The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.

A species of palm (Borassus flabelliformis) having a straight, black, upright trunk, with palmate leaves. It is found native along the entire northern shores of the Indian Ocean, from the mouth of the Tigris to New Guinea. More than eight hundred uses to which it is put are enumerated by native writers. Its wood is largely used for building purposes; its fruit and roots serve for food, its sap for making toddy, and its leaves for thatching huts.

The act of pitching or throwing one's self headlong or violently forward, like an unruly horse.
Consisting of more letters than three.

A combining form from Gr. pney^ma, pney`matos, wind, air, breath, respiration; as, pneumatograph, pneumatology.
A division of holothurians having an internal gill, or respiratory tree.
A large bag or sack used in packing various articles, as ginger, hops, cowries, etc.
A capsule of plant, especially a legume; a dry dehiscent fruit. See Illust. of Angiospermous.
A combining form or prefix from Gr. poy`s, podo`s, foot; as, podocarp, podocephalous, podology.
Specifically: Of or pertaining to, or characterizing, Triassic and Permian sandstones of red and other colors.
An exclamation expressing contempt or disgust; bah !

A large North American herb of the genus Phytolacca (P. decandra), bearing dark purple juicy berries; -- called also garget, pigeon berry, pocan, and pokeweed. The root and berries have emetic and purgative properties, and are used in medicine. The young shoots are sometimes eaten as a substitute for asparagus, and the berries are said to be used in Europe to color wine.
A native or inhabitant of Poland; a Pole.
of Pole
An extortioner. See Poller.
To regulate by laws; to reduce to order.
Of or pertaining to polity, or civil government; political; as, the body politic. See under Body.
A number or aggregate of heads; a list or register of heads or individuals.
The fecundating dustlike cells of the anthers of flowers. See Flower, and Illust. of Filament.
To render ceremonially unclean; to disqualify or unfit for sacred use or service, or for social intercourse.

Capable of neutralizing, or of combining with, several molecules of a monobasic acid; having more than one hydrogen atom capable of being replaced by acid radicals; -- said of certain bases; as, calcium hydrate and glycerin are polyacid bases.
A chloride containing more than one atom of chlorine in the molecule.
A division of Radiolaria. It includes those having one more central capsules.
Having many distinct sources; originating at various places or times.
A Linnaean order of plants having many styles.

By analogy with the French portail, used by recent writers for the whole architectural composition which surrounds and includes the doorways and porches of a church.

A white robe with a purple border, worn by a Roman boy before he was entitled to wear the toga virilis, or until about the completion of his fourteenth year, and by girls until their marriage. It was also worn by magistrates and priests.

Grass-green; clear, lively green, without any mixture.

Situated in front of any transverse axis in the body of an animal; anterior; cephalic; esp., in front, or on the anterior, or cephalic (that is, radial or tibial) side of the axis of a limb.
The act or state of going or being before in rank or dignity, or the place of honor; right to a more honorable place; superior rank; as, barons have precedence of commoners.

To proclaim; to publish; also, to summon; to call.

One who predestinates, or foreordains.
That which is affirmed or denied of the subject. In these propositions, "Paper is white,"  "Ink is not white,"  whiteness is the predicate affirmed of paper and denied of ink.
The act of predisposing, or the state of being predisposed; previous inclination, tendency, or propensity; predilection; -- applied to the mind; as, a predisposition to anger.

By way of preparation.
of Preponderate
A bone or cartilage, of some animals, situated in the middle line in front of the pubic bones.

A defect of vision consequent upon advancing age. It is due to rigidity of the crystalline lens, which produces difficulty of accommodation and recession of the near point of vision, so that objects very near the eyes can not be seen distinctly without the use of convex glasses. Called also presbytia.
To consider by a separate act of attention or analysis.
Previous perception.
The act of offering a clergyman to the bishop or ordinary for institution in a benefice; the right of presenting a clergyman.

imp. & p. p. of Press.
To take or suppose to be true, or entitled to belief, without examination or proof, or on the strength of probability; to take for granted; to infer; to suppose.

Hence, a mayor or magistrate.

The quality or condition of being prevalent; superior strength, force, or influence; general existence, reception, or practice; wide extension; as, the prevalence of virtue, of a fashion, or of a disease; the prevalence of a rumor.

One who, or that which, preys; a plunderer; a waster; a devourer.

That which comes forth or results; effect; yield; issue; product; sum accruing from a sale, etc.

To contrive; to bring about; to effect; to cause.
The quality or state of being prodigious; the state of having qualities that excite wonder or astonishment; enormousness; vastness.

An order of Arachnoidea having the palpi terminated by large claws, as in the scorpions, but destitute of a caudal sting; the false scorpions. Called also Pseudoscorpii, and Pseudoscorpionina. See Illust. of Book scorpion, under Book.

Mortar or the like, laid between the joists under the boards of a floor, or within a partition, to deaden sound; -- in the United States usually called deafening.

That which holds back, or causes to recede; a drawback; a hindrance.

Native lead phosphate with lead chloride, occurring in bright green and brown hexagonal crystals and also massive; -- so called because a fused globule crystallizes in cooling.
Caustic. See Caustic.
The doctrines of Pythagoras or the Pythagoreans.

the seventeenth letter of the English alphabet, has but one sound (that of k), and is always followed by u, the two letters together being sounded like kw, except in some words in which the u is silent. See Guide to Pronunciation, / 249. Q is not found in Anglo-Saxon, cw being used instead of qu; as in cwic, quick; cwen, queen. The name (k/) is from the French ku, which is from the Latin name of the same letter; its form is from the Latin, which derived it, through a Greek alphabet, from the Ph/nician, the ultimate origin being Egyptian.
Consisting of forty; forty years old.
Tetragonal.

of Quadruplicate

Specifically, the term, originally of forty days, during which a ship arriving in port, and suspected of being infected a malignant contagious disease, is obliged to forbear all intercourse with the shore; hence, such restraint or inhibition of intercourse; also, the place where infected or prohibited vessels are stationed.
Same as 1st Quarrel.
That part on either side of a horse's hoof between the toe and heel, being the side of the coffin.

A form of silica, or silicon dioxide (SiO2), occurring in hexagonal crystals, which are commonly colorless and transparent, but sometimes also yellow, brown, purple, green, and of other colors; also in cryptocrystalline massive forms varying in color and degree of transparency, being sometimes opaque.
The number four.

Any one of several kinds of apples, as summer queening, scarlet queening, and early queening. An apple called the queening was cultivated in England two hundred years ago.

Rasplike; as, raduliform teeth.

Full of rage; expressing rage.
An outer cloak or covering; a neckerchief for women.
To fall in drops from the clouds, as water; -- used mostly with it for a nominative; as, it rains.
To give vent or utterance to; to utter; to strike up.

A division into principal and subordinate classes, heads, or departments; also, one of the subordinate parts; as, the ramifications of a subject or scheme.

To have a certain direction; to correspond in direction; to be or keep in a corresponding line; to trend or run; -- often followed by with; as, the front of a house ranges with the street; to range along the coast.

More readily or willingly; preferably.

To attain or obtain by stretching forth the hand; to extend some part of the body, or something held by one, so as to touch, strike, grasp, or the like; as, to reach an object with the hand, or with a spear.

Offering itself at once; at hand; opportune; convenient; near; easy.

A bird belonging to the tribe of which the genus Tetrao is the type, as the grouse, partridge, quail, and the like. Used also adjectively.
A salt of tetrathionic acid.
A genus of small grasshoppers.
A book with wide spaces between the lines, to give room for notes.

In Old English, the article the, when the following word began with a vowel, was often written with elision as if a part of the word. Thus in Chaucer, the forms thabsence, tharray, thegle, thend, thingot, etc., are found for the absence, the array, the eagle, the end, etc.
Resembling, or consisting of, thallus.
The act of rending thanks, or expressing gratitude for favors or mercies.
Feats of legerdemain, or magical performances.
Alt. of Theatine
To thrive; to prosper.
At that time; then; in those days; -- correlative to nowadays.
A pretender or quack in theology.
Divinely inspired; theopneustic.
Alt. of Theosopher
Alt. of Therebiforn

An ancient composition esteemed efficacious against the effects of poison; especially, a certain compound of sixty-four drugs, prepared, pulverized, and reduced by means of honey to an electuary; -- called also theriaca Andromachi, and Venice treacle.
Producing heat; thermogenic.
of Thesaurus
The plural of he, she, or it. They is never used adjectively, but always as a pronoun proper, and sometimes refers to persons without an antecedent expressed.
To become thick.
That which is stolen.
Slight; small; slender; flimsy; wanting substance or depth or force; superficial; inadequate; not sufficient for a covering; as, a thin disguise.
One who thins, or makes thinner.
In the third place.
The sum of three tens, or twenty and ten; thirty units or objects.
A follower of Thomas Aquinas. See Scotist.
To prick, as with a thorn.
Fully accomplished; thoroughplaced.
Consisting of ten hundred; being ten times one hundred.
Alt. of Thresh
Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Polynemus and allied genera. They have numerous long pectoral filaments.
Having three prominent longitudinal angles; as, a three-cornered stem.
The doctrine of nutrition; a treatise on nutrition.
The quality or state of being thrifty; thrift.
To increase in bulk or stature; to grow vigorously or luxuriantly, as a plant; to flourish; as, young cattle thrive in rich pastures; trees thrive in a good soil.
The obstruction of a blood vessel by a clot formed at the site of obstruction; -- distinguished from embolism, which is produced by a clot or foreign body brought from a distance.
To compress the throat of; to choke; to strangle.
To put on hastily; to spread carelessly.
To insert short pieces of rope-yarn or spun yarn in; as, to thrum a piece of canvas, or a mat, thus making a rough or tufted surface.
Thrice.
To give a thump or thumps; to strike or fall with a heavy blow; to pound.
A thunderbolt, -- formerly believed to be a stone.
To this degree or extent; so far; so; as, thus wise; thus peaceble; thus bold.
A compound of thymol analogous to a salt; as, sodium thymate.

An emphasized form of the personal pronoun of the second person; -- used as a subject commonly with thou; as, thou thyself shalt go; that is, thou shalt go, and no other. It is sometimes used, especially in the predicate, without thou, and in the nominative as well as in the objective case.

Any one of numerous species of large parasitic mites which attach themselves to, and suck the blood of, cattle, dogs, and many other animals. When filled with blood they become ovate, much swollen, and usually livid red in color. Some of the species often attach themselves to the human body. The young are active and have at first but six legs.
To excite the sensation of titillation.
The period of twelve hours.
A knot; a fastening.
A triplet; three lines, or three lines rhyming together.
Firmly held together; compact; not loose or open; as, tight cloth; a tight knot.
A plate, or thin piece, of baked clay, used for covering the roofs of buildings, for floors, for drains, and often for ornamental mantel works.
To prepare; to get.
To cover with a tilt, or awning.
Woods or forest; wooden land.
The present life; existence in this world as contrasted with immortal life; definite, as contrasted with infinite, duration.
A timekeeper; especially, a watch by which small intervals of time can be measured; a kind of stop watch. It is used for timing the speed of horses, machinery, etc.
To cover with tin or tinned iron, or to overlay with tin foil.
Same as Tinean.
To mend or solder, as metal wares; hence, more generally, to mend.
of Tinsel
of Tip
An officer who bears a staff tipped with metal; a constable.
Untiring.
A woman; -- used in contempt.
A parish officer elected annually to preserve good order in the church during divine service, to make complaint of any disorderly conduct, and to enforce the observance of the Sabbath.
The hedge sparrow; -- called also titlene. Its nest often chosen by the cuckoo as a place for depositing its own eggs.
In a titular manner; nominally; by title only.
Like a toad.
A stout twilled silk used for dresses.
One of the terminal members, or digits, of the foot of a man or an animal.
Clothes; garments; dress; as, fishing toggery.
Ten and a half quires, or, commonly, 250 sheets, of paper printed on both sides; also, in some cases, the same number of sheets printed on one side, or half the number printed on both sides.
To draw; to entice; to allure. See Tole.
A fragrant balsam said to have been first brought from Santiago de Tolu, in New Granada. See Balsam of Tolu, under Balsam.

An alloy of copper and zinc, resembling brass, and containing about 84 per cent of copper; -- called also German, / Dutch, brass. It is very malleable and ductile, and when beaten into thin leaves is sometimes called Dutch metal. The addition of arsenic makes white tombac.
A rude, wild, wanton girl; a hoiden; a tomboy.
Having (such) a tone; -- chiefly used in composition; as, high-toned; sweet-toned.
To join means of a tongue and grove; as, to tongue boards together.
The seed of a leguminous tree (Dipteryx odorata), native of Guiana. It has a peculiarly agreeable smell, and is employed in the scenting of snuff. Called also tonquin bean.
A simpleton.
Fig.: Taste; palate.

A child's toy, commonly in the form of a conoid or pear, made to spin on its point, usually by drawing off a string wound round its surface or stem, the motion being sometimes continued by means of a whip.
A large ironbound block strapped with a hook, and, when used, hung to an eyebolt in the cap, -- used in swaying and lowering the topmast.

One of the mineral concretions about the joints, and in other situations, occurring chiefly in gouty persons. They consist usually of urate of sodium; when occurring in the internal organs they are also composed of phosphate of calcium.
Hence, assuming superiority; proud.
Alt. of Torase
of Torment
A kind of shell or cartridge buried in earth, to be exploded by electricity or by stepping on it.
To subject to scorching heat, so as to drive off volatile ingredients; to roast, as ores.
A roundel of a red color.
To wrest from the proper meaning; to distort.
To cause to rise and fall; as, a ship tossed on the waves in a storm.
To carry or bear; as, to tote a child over a stream; -- a colloquial word of the Southern States, and used esp. by negroes.
of Touch
A small quantity intermixed; a little; a dash.
Severe; violent; as, a tough storm.
A tournament.
A towel.
Hence, extreme; violent; surpassing.
A path traveled by men or animals in towing boats; -- called also towing path.
This year.
To copy; to imitate.
Goiter.
One who has charge of the track; -- called also roadmaster.
That which draws, or is used for drawing.
A mechanic or artificer; esp., one whose livelihood depends upon the labor of his hands.
To transfer; to transmit; to hand down; as, to traduce mental qualities to one's descendants.
Capable of being disposed of in traffic; marketable.
To grow to great length, especially when slender and creeping upon the ground, as a plant; to run or climb.
The number of beats of a watch in any certain time.
of Traject
A beam compass. See under Beam.
One who tramples; one who treads down; as, a trampler on nature's law.
Quality or state of being tranquil.
Transcending, or reaching beyond, the limits of human knowledge; -- applied to affirmations and speculations concerning what lies beyond the reach of the human intellect.
To run or rove to and fro.
One who makes a transfer or conveyance.
One who, or that which, transforms. Specif. (Elec.), an apparatus for producing from a given electrical current another current of different voltage.
Alt. of Transiency
To change to another condition, position, place, or office; to transfer; hence, to remove as by death.
Lying or being beyond the sea.
The quality of being transmutable.
Transparent; pervious to the sight.
To carry or bear from one place to another; to remove; to convey; as, to transport goods; to transport troops.
A change of the natural order of words in a sentence; as, the Latin and Greek languages admit transposition, without inconvenience, to a much greater extent than the English.
Running or lying across; transverse; as, a transversal line.
To set traps for game; to make a business of trapping game; as, to trap for beaver.
One who traps animals; one who makes a business of trapping animals for their furs.
Same as Tranter.
Across; athwart.

A white concretionary form of calcium carbonate, usually hard and semicrystalline. It is deposited from the water of springs or streams holding lime in solution. Extensive deposits exist at Tivoli, near Rome.
A sovereign remedy; a cure.
Spurge nettle. See under Nettle.
To entreat; to beseech.
Same as Triblet.
Any plant of the genus Trifolium, which includes the white clover, red clover, etc.; -- less properly, applied also to the nonesuch, or black medic. See Clover, and Medic.
Alt. of Tremulent
of Trend
Trepidation.
Tractable; moderate.
Examination by a test; experiment, as in chemistry, metallurgy, etc.
Having three joints.

Anciently, a bench or elevated place, from which speeches were delivered; in France, a kind of pulpit in the hall of the legislative assembly, where a member stands while making an address; any place occupied by a public orator.
A period of three centuries, or three hundred years, also, the three-hundredth anniversary of any event; a tercentenary.
Exhibiting trichroism; pleochroic; pleochroism.
One who tricks; a deceiver; a tricker; a cheat.
Short and ready; fleet; as, a tride pace; -- a term used by sportsmen.
At Athens, one who (singly, or jointly with other citizens) had to fit out a trireme for the public service.
Having a triple form or character.
A smooth triangular area on the inner surface of the bladder, limited by the apertures of the ureters and urethra.
Alt. of Triliteralness
of Trim
One who trims, arranges, fits, or ornaments.
The doctrine of the Trinity; the doctrine that there are three distinct persons in the Godhead.
See Olein.
Divisible into three parts.
Three-fold; triple; treble.
Of or pertaining to tripoli, the mineral.
Having three right angles. See Triquadrantal.
Arranged in three vertical rows.
A zooid of the third generation in asexual reproduction.
Having or celebrating a triumph; victorious; triumphant.
Occurring or appearing three times a week; thriceweekly; as, a triweekly newspaper.
See Trochiscus.
Native iron protosulphide, FeS. It is known only in meteoric irons, and is usually in imbedded nodular masses of a bronze color.
A revolving buddle or sieve for separating, or sizing, ores.
The word or expression so used.
To proceed by a certain gait peculiar to quadrupeds; to ride or drive at a trot. See Trot, n.
A pit in the form of an inverted cone or pyramid, constructed as an obstacle to the approach of an enemy, and having a pointed stake in the middle. The pits are called also trapholes.
See Troll.
of Truck

Steady in adhering to friends, to promises, to a prince, or the like; unwavering; faithful; loyal; not false, fickle, or perfidious; as, a true friend; a wife true to her husband; an officer true to his charge.
To blow a trumpet.
The sea trumpet.
To go or move on small wheels; as, a bed trundles under another.
A bundle; a package; as, a truss of grass.
To give credit to; to sell to upon credit, or in confidence of future payment; as, merchants and manufacturers trust their customers annually with goods.
One who loves the truth.
An appointment to meet; also, an appointed place or time of meeting; as, to keep tryst; to break tryst.
A telescope.
A plant (Polianthes tuberosa) with a tuberous root and a liliaceous flower. It is much cultivated for its beautiful and fragrant white blossoms.
Any hydroid belonging to the suborder Tubularida.
A small net used for taking fish from a larger one; -- called also tuck-net.
To adorn with tufts or with a tuft.
Any plant of the liliaceous genus Tulipa. Many varieties are cultivated for their beautiful, often variegated flowers.
a. & vb. n. from Tumble, v.
The quality or state of being tumulous; hilliness.
Capable of being tuned, or made harmonious; hence, harmonious; musical; tuneful.
Any similar garment worm by ancient or Oriental peoples; also, a common name for various styles of loose-fitting under-garments and over-garments worn in modern times by Europeans and others.

Any one of several species of large oceanic fishes belonging to the Mackerel family, especially the common or great tunny (Orcynus / Albacora thynnus) native of the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. It sometimes weighs a thousand pounds or more, and is extensively caught in the Mediterranean. On the American coast it is called horse mackerel. See Illust. of Horse mackerel, under Horse.
Disturbed; confused; disordered.
Disposed to insubordination and disorder; restless; unquiet; refractory; as, turbulent spirits.
of Turgesce
One of a body of native Algerian tirailleurs in the French army, dressed as a Turk.

To be changed, altered, or transformed; to become transmuted; also, to become by a change or changes; to grow; as, wood turns to stone; water turns to ice; one color turns to another; to turn Mohammedan.
A person who practices athletic or gymnastic exercises.
A turnpike road.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina containing a little copper; calaite. It has a blue, or bluish green, color, and usually occurs in reniform masses with a botryoidal surface.
A long, pointed tooth; a tusk; -- applied especially to certain teeth of horses.
A snub nose.
Silly talk; gabble; fustian.
A soft and flexible fabric for men's wear, made wholly of wool except in some inferior kinds, the wool being dyed, usually in two colors, before weaving.
of Twenty
To twit.
Born at the same birth.
A closing or opening, or a quick motion, of the eye; a wink or sparkle of the eye.
To unite by winding one thread, strand, or other flexible substance, round another; to form by convolution, or winding separate things round each other; as, to twist yarn or thread.
The act of twitching; a pull with a jerk; a short, sudden, quick pull; as, a twitch by the sleeve.
In a double degree; doubly.
The act or process of washing ores in a buddle.
The ear drum, or middle ear. Sometimes applied incorrectly to the tympanic membrane. See Ear.
An instrument for writing by means of type, a typewheel, or the like, in which the operator makes use of a sort of keyboard, in order to obtain printed impressions of the characters upon paper.
A stone or fossil which has on it impressions or figures of plants and animals.
The state of being a tyro, or beginner; apprenticeship.
A tribe of North American Indians belonging to the Creek confederation.
To ulcerate.
of Ulnare
Going beyond others, or beyond due limit; extreme; fanatical; uncompromising; as, an ultra reformer; ultra measures.
A small or partial umbel; an umbellule.
The entrails and coarser parts of a deer; hence, sometimes, entrails, in general.

In ancient armor, a visor, or projection like the peak of a cap, to which a face guard was sometimes attached. This was sometimes fixed, and sometimes moved freely upon the helmet and could be raised like the beaver. Called also umber, and umbril.
Un- is prefixed to nouns to express the absence of, or the contrary of, that which the noun signifies; as, unbelief, unfaith, unhealth, unrest, untruth, and the like.
Not prudent; not discreet; ill advised.
Inapplicable.
Incapable of being atoned for; inexpiable.
To deprive of the bark; to decorticate; to strip; as, to unbark a tree.
Believing the thing alleged no to be true; disbelieving; especially, believing that Bible is not a divine revelation, or that Christ was not a divine or a supernatural person.
of Unbind
imp. & p. p. of Unbind.
To relieve from a burden.
Incautiously.
The quality or state of being unchaste; lewdness; incontinence.
Not circumstantial; not entering into minute particulars.
Divested or stripped of clothing.
Not concerned; not anxious or solicitous; easy in mind; carelessly secure; indifferent; as, to be unconcerned at what has happened; to be unconcerned about the future.
Not considered or attended to; not regarded; inconsiderable; trifling.
Unknown.
Of the nature or quality of an unguent or ointment; fatty; oily; greasy.
Waving or wavy; -- applied to ordinaries, or division lines.

Denoting relation to some thing or person that is superior, weighs upon, oppresses, bows down, governs, directs, influences powerfully, or the like, in a relation of subjection, subordination, obligation, liability, or the like; as, to travel under a heavy load; to live under extreme oppression; to have fortitude under the evils of life; to have patience under pain, or under misfortunes; to behave like a Christian under reproaches and injuries; under the pains and penalties of the law; the condition under which one enters upon an office; under the necessity of obeying the laws; under vows of chastity.
To charge below or under; to charge less than is usual or suitable fro; as, to undercharge goods or services.
To drain by forming an underdrain or underdrains in; as, to underdrain land.
To gore underneath.
To join below or beneath; to subjoin.
Insufficiently furnished with men; short-handed.
The act of one who underpins; the act of supporting by stones, masonry, or the like.
To sell the same articles at a lower price than; to sell cheaper than.
To raise with a spar, or piece of wood, used as a lever.
One who studies another's part with a view to assuming it in an emergency.
The current that sets seaward near the bottom when waves are breaking upon the shore.
The portion of the world which is below the horizon; the opposite side of the world; the antipodes.
Not directed; not guided; left without direction.
To unfold, or render single.
The pulsation caused by the vibrating together of two tones not quite in unison; -- called also beat.
Inelasticity.
Something not constituting essence, or something which is not of absolute necessity; as, forms are among the unessentials of religion.
Not failing; not liable to fail; inexhaustible; certain; sure.

To make unsuitable or incompetent; to deprive of the strength, skill, or proper qualities for anything; to disable; to incapacitate; to disqualify; as, sickness unfits a man for labor; sin unfits us for the society of holy beings.
Not fraught; not burdened.
Being without gifts, especially native gifts or endowments.
Having a nail, claw, or hoof attached; -- said of certain bones of the feet.
Same as Ungulate.
Not known to fame; not illustrious or celebrated; obscure.
Driven from a house; deprived of shelter.
That can be passed over in a single course; -- said of a curve when the coordinates of the point on the curve can be expressed as rational algebraic functions of a single parameter /.
of Unify
Agreement and conjunction of mind, spirit, will, affections, or the like; harmony; concord.

Having one sex only, as plants which have the male and female flowers on separate individuals, or animals in which the sexes are in separate individuals; di/cious; -- distinguished from bisexual, or hermaphrodite. See Di/cious.
To join in an act; to concur; to act in concert; as, all parties united in signing the petition.
A general abstract conception, so called from being universally applicable to, or predicable of, each individual or species contained under it.
To disjoin.
To free from knots; to untie.
To untwist; as, to unlay a rope.
To take the load from; to discharge of a load or cargo; to disburden; as, to unload a ship; to unload a beast.
To divest of the office or authority of a magistrate.
Unmerciful; merciless.
To change the nature of; to invest with a different or contrary nature.
Disorderly; irregular; inordinate.
Not paved; not furnished with a pavement.
Destitute of pity; pitiless.
To deprive of a pope.
Want of proficiency or improvement.
To become unraveled, in any sense.
Want of remembrance; forgetfulness.
Not righteous; evil; wicked; sinful; as, an unrighteous man.
Quality or state unruly.
Destitute of an escutcheon.
Inseparable.
The act of unshipping, or the state of being unshipped; displacement.
To loose or take from a socket.
To divest of the title or privilege of an esquire.
Lacking in matter or substance; visionary; chimerical.
Intangibility.
Improperly; unbecomingly.
To take out the teeth of.
Not to be trusted; not trusty.
To deprive of the position or office a vicar.
Not weighed; not pondered or considered; as, an unweighed statement.
To undo or destroy, as work previously done.
Upon.
To taunt; to reproach; to upbraid.
Upwards on, or as on, a hillside; as, to walk uphill.
A line or track leading from the provinces toward the metropolis or a principal terminus; the track upon which up-trains run. See Up-train.
An insurrection; a popular revolt.
To soar or mount up.
To tear up.
Of or pertaining to the Urals and the Altai; as the Ural-Altaic, or Turanian, languages.
Observation of the heavens or heavenly bodies.
The urchin, or hedgehog.
To present in an urgent manner; to press upon attention; to insist upon; as, to urge an argument; to urge the necessity of a case.

A vessel of various forms, usually a vase furnished with a foot or pedestal, employed for different purposes, as for holding liquids, for ornamental uses, for preserving the ashes of the dead after cremation, and anciently for holding lots to be drawn.
A urohyal bone or cartilage.

One of an order of nuns founded by St. Angela Merici, at Brescia, in Italy, about the year 1537, and so called from St. Ursula, under whose protection it was placed. The order was introduced into Canada as early as 1639, and into the United States in 1727. The members are devoted entirely to education.
Continued or repeated practice; customary employment; usage; custom; manner; habit.
A compound distilled spirit made in Ireland and Scotland; whisky.
Use; usage; custom.
The act of utilizing, or the state of being utilized.
Situated on the outside, or extreme limit; remote from the center; outer.
See Euphroe.
To defeat; to put an end to.
To make void, or empty.
Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves; pneumogastric.
Wandering from place to place without any settled habitation; as, a vagrant beggar.
The quality or state of being vain.
Any plant of the genus Valeriana. The root of the officinal valerian (V. officinalis) has a strong smell, and is much used in medicine as an antispasmodic.
The quality or state of being valid; strength; force; especially, power to convince; justness; soundness; as, the validity of an argument or proof; the validity of an objection.
Of or pertaining to Valsalva, an Italian anatomist of the 17th century.

A lid, plug, or cover, applied to an aperture so that by its movement, as by swinging, lifting and falling, sliding, turning, or the like, it will open or close the aperture to permit or prevent passage, as of a fluid.
Fig.: The practice of extortion.
One of the sights of a compass, quadrant, etc.
of Vanquish
Capable of being converted into vapor by the agency of heat; vaporizable.
One of the Northmen who founded a dynasty in Russia in the 9th century; also, one of the Northmen composing, at a later date, the imperial bodyguard at Constantinople.
Irregularly swollen or enlarged; affected with, or containing, varices, or varicosities; of or pertaining to varices, or varicosities; as, a varicose nerve fiber; a varicose vein; varicose ulcers.
The smallpox as modified by previous inoculation or vaccination.
of Vary

Causing constriction of the blood vessels; as, the vasoconstrictor nerves, stimulation of which causes constriction of the blood vessels to which they go.  These nerves are also called vasohypertonic.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropods having massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on the columella.
of Vault
The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, the lands held by a vavasor.
A vegetable.
Conveyed in a vehicle; furnished with a vehicle.
Full of veins; streaked; variegated; as, veined marble.
An apparatus for measuring speed, as of machinery or vessels, but especially of projectiles.
of Vena
See Wends.
Consisting of, or pertaining to, copper, formerly called by chemists Venus.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison.
A belly, or protuberant part; a broad surface; as, the venter of a muscle; the venter, or anterior surface, of the scapula.
Fig.: Any cavity, or hollow place, in which any function may be conceived of as operating.
A strumpet; a prostitute.
Abounding with words; verbose.
Greenness; freshness.
A rod or staff, carried as an emblem of authority; as, the verge, carried before a dean.
One who, or that which, verifies.

Of or pertaining to a worm or worms; resembling a worm; shaped like a worm; especially, resembling the motion or track of a worm; as, the vermicular, or peristaltic, motion of the intestines.  See Peristaltic.
Resembling vermin; in the manner of vermin.
A genus scrophulariaceous plants; the speedwell.  See Speedwell.
To make verses; to versify.
Everything that grows, and bears a green leaf, within the forest; as, to preserve vert and venison is the duty of the verderer.
The quality or state of being vertical; verticalness.
A vesicatory.
Vesper; evening.
To invest; to put; as, to vest money in goods, land, or houses.
A member of a vestry; especially (Prot. Epis. Ch.), a member other than a warden.  See Vestry.
A vettura.
By the way of; as, to send a letter via Queenstown to London.
To mark or measure by moving to and fro; as, a pendulum vibrating seconds.
Acting of suffering for another; as, a vicarious agent or officer.
Fault; defect; coarseness.
The winner in a contest; one who gets the better of another in any struggle; esp., one who defeats an enemy in battle; a vanquisher; a conqueror; -- often followed by art, rarely by of.
The whidah bird.
To survey or examine mentally; to consider; as, to view the subject in all its aspects.
Of or pertaining to the vicu/a; characterizing the vicu/a; -- said of the wool of that animal, used in felting hats, and for other purposes.
Villages; a district of villages.
Villanage.
Capable of being overcome or subdued; conquerable.
Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines.
One who gathers the vintage.
Injury done to that which is entitled to respect, reverence, or observance; profanation; infringement; unjust force; outrage; assault.
