An instrument somewhat resembling the spinet, but having a rectangular form, like the small piano. It had strings and keys, but only one wire to a note. The instrument was used in the sixteenth century, but is now wholly obsolete. It was sometimes called a pair of virginals.
The quality or state of being virtual.
In a virulent manner.
An instrument for measuring the degree of viscosity of liquids, as solutions of gum.
Of or pertaining to a vision.
One who visits; one who comes or goes to see another, as in civility or friendship.
of Vitalize
Consisting of, or resembling, glass; glassy; as, vitreous rocks.
The act of vitriolizing, or the state of being vitriolized; vitriolation.
Long live, that is, success to; as, vive le roi, long live the king; vive la bagatelle, success to trifles or sport.
A vivisectionist.
A singer, or vocal musician, as opposed to an instrumentalist.
Same as Vugg.
of Void
A cumbrous two-wheeled pleasure carriage used in Cuba.
To subject to, or cause to undergo, volcanic heat, and to be affected by its action.
To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers.
Anything of a rounded or swelling form resembling a roll; a turn; a convolution; a coil.

A grantee in a voluntary conveyance; one to whom a conveyance is made without valuable consideration; a party, other than a wife or child of the grantor, to whom, or for whose benefit, a voluntary conveyance is made.
An abscess in any other parenchymatous organ.
Any one of numerous species of small Turbellaria belonging to Vortex and allied genera.  See Illustration in Appendix.
To call; to summon.
Of the nature of a vowel.
of Vulcanize
Alt. of Vulnifical
Woad.
One who holds by a wadset.
To be in action or motion; to move; to get along; to progress; to stir.
Like a wag; mischievous in sport; roguish in merriment or good humor; frolicsome.

Goods found of which the owner is not known; originally, such goods as a pursued thief threw away to prevent being apprehended, which belonged to the king unless the owner made pursuit of the felon, took him, and brought him to justice.
That part of the human body which is immediately below the ribs or thorax; the small part of the body between the thorax and hips.
A woman put out of the protection of the law.  See Waive, v. t., 3 (b), and the Note.
To excite; to rouse; to move to action; to awaken.
To move off; to depart.
A leguminous tree (Eperua falcata) of Demerara, with pinnate leaves and clusters of red flowers. The reddish brown wood is used for palings and shingles.
To wrap up temporarily.
Disturbance of the stomach; a feeling of nausea.
Decline; failure; diminution; decrease; declension.
That which is wanting; deficiency.
An exhibition of arms. according to the rank of the individual, by all persons bearing arms; -- formerly made at certain seasons in each district.
To be quavered or modulated; to be uttered melodiously.
Guardian; one set to watch over another.
A storehouse for wares, or goods.
Quality of being warlike.
The glowing effect which arises from the use of warm colors; hence, any similar appearance or effect in a painting, or work of color.
A rope used in hauling or moving a vessel, usually with one end attached to an anchor, a post, or other fixed object; a towing line; a warping hawser.
One who warrants, gives authority, or legally empowers.
Same as Wartwort.
A liquid preparation for the hair; as, a hair wash.
The clothes washed, esp. at one time; a wash.
To bring to ruin; to devastate; to desolate; to destroy.
Anything cast away as bad or useless, as imperfect bricks, china, etc.
The fluid which descends from the clouds in rain, and which forms rivers, lakes, seas, etc.
The American hornbeam.  See Hornbeam.
The American lotus, and its edible seeds, which somewhat resemble chinquapins.   Cf. Yoncopin.
A sailor, esp. an old sailor; an old salt.
An instrument for measuring or ascertaining the depth or quantity of water, or for indicating the height of its surface, as in the boiler of a steam engine.  See Gauge.
The common sandpiper.
The shrew mole.  See under Shrew.
A kind of plant with acrid leaves.  See under 2d Plantain.
To ret, or rot, in water, as flax; to water-rot.
Any spider that habitually lives on or about the water, especially the large American species (Dolomedes lanceolatus) which runs rapidly on the surface of water; -- called also raft spider.
See under Vole.
To twist or interweave, one with another, as twigs; to form a network with; to plat; as, to wattle branches.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina, occurring usually in hemispherical radiated forms varying in color from white to yellow, green, or black.
A substance similar to beeswax, secreted by several species of scale insects, as the Chinese wax.  See Wax insect, below.
The longitudinal guides, or guiding surfaces, on the bed of a planer, lathe, or the like, along which a table or carriage moves.
Of or pertaining to the wayside; as, wayside flowers.
To make or become weak; to weaken.
Weal; welfare; prosperity; good.
To impair, waste, or diminish, by continual attrition, scraping, percussion, on the like; to consume gradually; to cause to lower or disappear; to spend.
Having a thin, sharp face, like a weasel.
Made sloping, so as to throw off water; as, a weathered cornice or window sill.
That which is woven; a texture; textile fabric; esp., something woven in a loom.
Having webbed feet; palmiped; as, a goose or a duck is a web-footed fowl.
To fasten with a wedge, or with wedges; as, to wedge a scythe on the snath; to wedge a rail or a piece of timber in its place.
One who, or that which, weeds, or frees from anything noxious.
One who weeps; esp., one who sheds tears.
Alt. of Wehrgelt
Hence, pressure; burden; as, the weight of care or business.
Surrounded with happiness or prosperity.
Faring well; prosperous; thriving.
Being in health; sound in body; not ailing, diseased, or sick; healthy; as, a well man; the patient is perfectly well.
Having seen much; hence, accomplished; experienced.
To wilt.
imp. of Wene.
An Australian lorikeet (Ptilosclera versicolor) noted for the variety of its colors; -- called also varied lorikeet.
A westerner.
To weigh.
To turn over.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as a polishing powder.

A small nematode worm (Anguillula tritici) which attacks the grains of wheat in the ear. It is found in wheat affected with smut, each of the diseased grains containing a large number of the minute young of the worm.
A wheel horse.  See under Wheel.
Shelly.
Whereas.
Through which.
A sound like a half-formed whistle, expressing astonishment, scorn, or dislike.
To disperse with, or as with, a whiff, or puff; to scatter.
During the time that; while.
A whimsey.
To drive with lashes or strokes of a whip; to cause to rotate by lashing with a cord; as, to whip a top.
A huntsman who keeps the hounds from wandering, and whips them in, if necessary, to the of chase.
A turning with rapidity or velocity; rapid rotation or circumvolution; quick gyration; rapid or confusing motion; as, the whirl of a top; the whirl of a wheel.
of Whisk
To make a low, sibilant sound or noise.
The ring ousel.
The American widgeon, or baldpate.
To grow white; to turn or become white or whiter; as, the hair whitens with age; the sea whitens with foam; the trees in spring whiten with blossoms.
A dangerous disease of sheep.
A sort of apple.
Whatever person; any person who; be or she who; any one who; as, he shall be punished, whoever he may be.
To hoot.
Hot.
Made of, or covered with, twigs or osiers, or wickerwork.
of Widen
of Wield
Having the head covered with a wig; wearing a wig.
Become wild.
Strong wish or inclination; desire; purpose.
To open and cleanse, as cotton, flax, or wool, by means of a willow.  See Willow, n., 2.
of Wimble
A crank with a handle, for giving motion to a machine, a grindstone, etc.
To drive hard, or force to violent exertion, as a horse, so as to render scant of wind; to put out of breath.
Twisting from a direct line or an even surface; circuitous.
Caused to ride or drive by the wind in opposition to the course of the tide; -- said of a vessel lying at anchor, with wind and tide opposed to each other.
destitute of wine; as, wineless life.
Furnished with a leaflike appendage, as the fruit of the elm and the ash, or the stem in certain plants; alate.
In a winking manner; with the eye almost closed.
To pass the winter; to hibernate; as, to winter in Florida.
A rod, or an attachment for a rod, for holding a rag with which to wipe out the bore of the barrel.
Made of wire; like wire; drawn out like wire.
One who wishes or desires; one who expresses a wish.
of Wit
Blameless.
of Withe
In the inner part; inwardly; internally.
One who is cognizant; a person who beholds, or otherwise has personal knowledge of, anything; as, an eyewitness; an earwitness.
To match to a wife; to provide with a wife.
Grief; sorrow; misery; heavy calamity.
A young wolf.
Without a woman or women.
See Wondrous.
A large and thick collection of trees; a forest or grove; -- frequently used in the plural.
Alt. of Woodhacker
A striped variety of hornstone, resembling wood in appearance.
Dyed before being made into cloth, in distinction from piece-dyed; ingrain.
Wept.

The matter on which one is at work; that upon which one spends labor; material for working upon; subject of exertion; the thing occupying one; business; duty; as, to take up one's work; to drop one's work.
A box for holding instruments or materials for work.
A week day or working day, as distinguished from Sunday or a holiday. Also used adjectively.
A short revolving screw, the threads of which drive, or are driven by, a worm wheel by gearing into its teeth or cogs.  See Illust. of Worm gearing, below.
Inclined to worry or fret; also, causing worry or annoyance.
To pay divine honors to; to reverence with supreme respect and veneration; to perform religious exercises in honor of; to adore; to venerate.
Of high station; of high social position.
Same as Curare.
To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt.
of Wreak
The remain of anything ruined or fatally injured.
of Wrest
To move the body to and fro with short, writhing motions, like a worm; to squirm; to twist uneasily or quickly about.
Full of wrinkles; having a tendency to be wrinkled; corrugated; puckered.
of Writhe
One who injures another, or who does wrong.
A twisted or distorted neck; a deformity in which the neck is drawn to one side by a rigid contraction of one of the muscles of the neck; torticollis.
Same as Wiver.
A yellow acid substance formed by the action of hot nitric acid on albuminous or proteid matter. It is changed to a deep orange-yellow color by the addition of ammonia.
A shereef.

Any of a group of three metameric hydrocarbons of the aromatic series, found in coal and wood tar, and so named because found in crude wood spirit. They are colorless, oily, inflammable liquids, C6H4.(CH3)2, being dimethyl benzenes, and are called respectively orthoxylene, metaxylene, and paraxylene. Called also xylol.
Of or pertaining to the genus Xylophaga.
Of or pertaining to a tribe (Zalambdodonta) of Insectivora in which the molar teeth have but one V-shaped ridge.
Native sulphide of arsenic, including sandarach, or realgar, and orpiment.
A medicinal substance obtained in the East Indies, having a fragrant smell, and a warm, bitter, aromatic taste. It is used in medicine as a stimulant.
The woody, thick skin inclosing the kernel of a walnut.
To move in a zigzag manner; also, to have a zigzag shape.
Hence, formerly, basic, basylous, as opposed to chlorous.
Same as Anthozoa.
A girdle; a cincture.
Of or pertaining to zoogeny, animal production.
Of or pertaining to animals; obtained from animal substances.
One who dissects animals, or is skilled in zootomy.
An Austrian silver coin equivalent to 20 kreutzers, or about 10 cents.
One of a physiological group of globular bacteria which produces fermentations of diverse nature; -- distinguished from pathogene.

A light and elegantly furnished vessel, used either for private parties of pleasure, or as a vessel of state to convey distinguished persons from one place to another; a seagoing vessel used only for pleasure trips, racing, etc.
Of or pertaining to a Yankee; characteristic of the Yankees.
A story told by a sailor for the amusement of his companions; a story or tale; as, to spin a yarn.
An involuntary act, excited by drowsiness, etc., consisting of a deep and long inspiration following several successive attempts at inspiration, the mouth, fauces, etc., being wide open.
An animal one year old, or in the second year of its age; -- applied chiefly to cattle, sheep, and horses.
To utter or declare with a yell; to proclaim in a loud tone.
Alt. of Yellowshins
The collective body of yeomen, or freeholders.
The week last past; last week.
of Yield
Among.
The quantity of land plowed in a day by a yoke of oxen.
To unite closely.
Also used figuratively.
A rare metallic element of the boron-aluminium group, found in gadolinite and other rare minerals, and extracted as a dark gray powder.  Symbol Y.  Atomic weight, 89.
